data.title: The History of Money in Nepal
data.meta_description: Discover the History of Money in Nepal in our blog.
data.meta_site_name: Royal Mountain Travel || For Tours & Treks in Nepal, Tibet & Bhutan
data.text:
Excavations in Tilaurkot during the period of 1967-1976 revealed that the earliest coins recorded in Nepal are ‘kushan’, ‘kaniksha’ and ‘havisha’ coins (1st century) and the ‘punch marked’ coins (6th and 5th century B.C.). King Mandeva’s rule in the 5th century gave birth to the Licchavi coins. During the Malla period, more systematisation was brought in monetary terms. Coins were then issued in denominations of 2 mohur (equivalent to one rupee), 1 mohur (50 paisa), one and a half sukka (36 paisa), sukka (25 paisa), sukki, or ‘tinnani’, (12 paisa), anni (6 paisa), adhani (3 paisa), paisa (1 paisa), and dam (1/4 paisa).

In 1545, Dolkha King Indrasinga Deva minted the first silver coins with the rupee coin weighing in at 11.6 gm (1 tola). During Mahendra Malla’s rule, the first silver coins were minted in the Valley, with each 1 tola coin being called a Mahendra Malli. The ‘windblown type’ silver coin called ‘Fukadam’ (‘Chundam’ in Newari) was made during Jayaprakash Malla’s reign in Kantipur. Guinness Book of Records has reportedly listed it as the world’s smallest coin.

During Prithivi Narayan’s reign, in 1754, the first Shah Dynasty coins were minted, and the first silver ‘mohur’ coins were minted. During Mathasingh’s brief reign (a Khasiya king who attacked the western Nepahe valley in 1328), while mostly noble and base metals like gold, silver, copper, nickel, brass and aluminium were used to make coins, coins made of clay were also issued. Such clay coins were given as tokens to labourers who, having collected a certain number, could exchange them for real coins.

At one point in the country’s history, leather coins, rumoured to be made by ‘Sarki’ (a clan that traditionally worked in leather) kings, were also used. During the 1640s, Nepali coins were used freely in Tibet. One such coin was known as ’15 karma’. It could be fragmented to get smaller denominations called ‘chotangs’. The coins had a design of eight petals and so, fragmentation was based on the number of petals. For instance, 5 petals equal 10 karma, 4 petals, 7 and a half karma and 3 petals, 5 karma. From the Licchavi period until 1945, denominations and rates of coins were determined by the weight of the metal used. It was in October 1945 that paper, when Rs.5, Rs.10 and Rs.100 bank money was first introduced here and notes were issued. Banknotes were known as ‘mohru’ until 1956.
